importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of the legal proceedings and public awareness of the case.
When authorities first began investigating Stanton's online activity after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center.
The date when a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor contacted Stanton, leading to further escalation of the case and hostile responses from Stanton.
The date of a video post four days before Stanton's arrest, in which he allegedly called for ICE agents to be shot.
Scheduled pretrial conference date, indicating the timeline for legal proceedings.
Scheduled trial date, marking the expected conclusion of the case in court.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Stanton posted multiple threatening TikTok videos, from August to October 2025, forming the core of the criminal allegations.

keyTakeAways: A Wisconsin man, Andrew Stanton, was charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder a U.S. official after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents.
Stanton's videos included specific calls to shoot ICE agents, such as 'If they (ICE) show up to your neighborhood…it’s time we start shooting at you,' and references to mass shootings.
He allegedly suggested applying violence to federal agents, referencing the September 10 murder of Charlie Kirk by saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.'
Federal investigators were alerted by the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center after a tip about an account linked to Stanton requesting information about Israeli military locations.
Stanton refused multiple attempts by federal law enforcement to speak with him, including a direct text from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor, and responded with hostility and threats.
The case highlights rising concerns over threats against federal immigration agents amid increased scrutiny of ICE’s enforcement tactics under the Trump administration.
Stanton is currently in federal detention pending trial, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025.
His attorney has emphasized that the criminal complaint contains only allegations and that Stanton is presumed innocent, pending a court verdict.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, who has been charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents through TikTok videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the case, directly linked to the criminal allegations of threatening ICE agents and advocating violence against federal officials through social media.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A popular social media platform where Andrew Stanton posted threatening videos advocating violence against ICE agents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as the medium through which Stanton disseminated his threats, illustrating how digital platforms can be used to spread extremist or violent content.

namedEntities.name: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency responsible for immigration enforcement and border security.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary target of Stanton’s threats, reflecting broader national tensions over immigration enforcement and public fear of attacks on federal agents.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist who was murdered on September 10, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton referenced the killing in a video, suggesting a pattern of glorifying violent acts, linking his rhetoric to real-world political violence.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that tracks suspected terrorist activity and suspicious behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided the initial tip that led to federal investigation into Stanton’s online behavior, marking the beginning of law enforcement's scrutiny.

namedEntities.name: United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal agency that oversees ICE and other immigration enforcement operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency has publicly stated it is targeting the 'worst of the worst' and has reported a surge in attacks on agents, providing context for the public concern over safety.

namedEntities.name: US Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement component within DHS that oversees border security.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A specific unit that engaged directly with Stanton, leading to a hostile exchange that intensified the investigation.

namedEntities.name: John Bradley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Stanton’s attorney, who has defended the case by emphasizing the allegations are unsubstantiated.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides a legal counterpoint to the prosecution, highlighting the presumption of innocence and the nature of criminal complaints as allegations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Andrew Stanton, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, has been charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder U.S. federal officials after posting a series of TikTok videos between August and October 2025. In those videos, he called for the shooting of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents, referenced the murder of conservative activist Charlie Kirk by suggesting 'doing a lot more Charlie Kirks,' and promoted the idea that violence against federal agents is justified. Federal investigators initiated the probe after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a request for information on Israeli military locations. Despite multiple attempts to contact him, Stanton refused to engage, including a hostile response to a direct message from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor. He is currently in federal detention pending a pretrial conference on December 1, 2025, and a trial on December 15, 2025. His attorney has stated that the criminal complaint contains only allegations and that Stanton is presumed innocent.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
